FMB_INLINE COORDINATES_T angle_Convert_in_MinusPi_Pi ( COORDINATES_T  a  ) 

This function gives the value in the range ]-Pi, Pi] which equals "a" modulo 2*Pi.

Definition at line 453 of file position.h.

References position_Set_x(), position_Set_y(), position_Set_z(), spherical_position_Get_ph(), spherical_position_Get_r(), and spherical_position_Get_th().

FMB_INLINE void spherical_position_Compute_cartesian_from_local_base ( FMB_CONST spherical_position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p_center_of_local_base,
FMB_CONST position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p_pos_in_local_base,
position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p_result 
)

  • *p_center_of_local_base are the spherical coordinates of the center of the local base of the spherical coordinates.
  • *p_pos_in_local_base are the cartesian coordinates of the vector in the local base of the spherical coordinates.
  • *p_result will contain (at the return of the function) the cartesian coordinate of the vector in the "usual" base of the cartesian coordinates centred in the origin.

Definition at line 574 of file position.h.

References position_Get_x(), position_Get_y(), position_Get_z(), position_Set_x(), position_Set_y(), position_Set_z(), spherical_position_Get_ph(), and spherical_position_Get_th().

FMB_CONST spherical_position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p_new_origin,
spherical_position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p_rel 
)

This function returns in *p_rel the relative spherical coordinates
of the *p_abs absolute coordinates with regard to *p_new_origin.

FMB_INLINE void spherical_position_Set_ph ( spherical_position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p,
COORDINATES_T  v 
)

The user do not need to ensure that v is in the range ]-Pi, Pi]. spherical_position_Set_ph() will automatically set phi to a value in the range ]-Pi, Pi].

FMB_INLINE void spherical_position_Set_r_th_ph ( spherical_position_t *FMB_RESTRICT  p,
COORDINATES_T  r_value,
COORDINATES_T  th_value,
COORDINATES_T  ph_value 
)

Use the following function whenever it is possible (instead of 3 calls
to: spherical_position_Set_r(), spherical_position_Set_th() and
spherical_position_Set_ph()) or be sure to call the 3 functions in the same
order as the one used in the definition of spherical_position_Set_r_th_ph()!
